trial_identification.scientifictitle: Wound Healing After Craniotomy : a randomised prospective trial comparing scalp clips to artery forceps as techniques of scalp haemostasis

conditions.healthcondition: Wound healing after craniotomy of greater than 2 hours' duration. The craniotomy can be for any of the appropriate indications, such as intra-cranial tumour, aneurysm etc.

interventions.interventions: We are comparing healing of the scalp wounds when Aesculap Rainey clips are used on the wound edge to obtain scalp haemostasis (comparison intervention), to the results when artery forceps are used (control). These devices are applied during the operation (2 to many hours), and then removed prior to closure of the wound.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Wound healing, as defined by a specific original scoring system, designed by the investigators and validated in a pilot study. The wounds are scored for completeness of healing, hair loss, and presence of infection, minor or major, leading to a score of 3-15.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: All patients undergoing de novo supra-tentorial craniotomy which is expected to last at least 2 hours.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Children, posterior fossa craniotomies, re-do craniotomies, and past irradiation.

trial_design.designfeatures: subjects and assessors will be blinded to the treatment group.

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Clinical Associate Professor R. Andrew Danks

secondarysponsor.sponsorname: University Department of Surgery, Monash Medical Centre

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The purpose is to study whether different techniques of haemostasis of the scalp edges during the operation of craniotomy lasting more than 2 hours have any influence on the speed and acceptability of healing of the wound
